\begin{itemize}
\item[1)] Prove $\lim\limits_{x \rightarrow -1} 2x+1=-1$

Solution: 

Determine $\delta > 0$ so that if $|x-(-1)| < \delta$ then $|2x+1-(-1)| < \epsilon$. 

$$
\begin{aligned}
|(2x+1)-(-1)| &< \epsilon \\
|2x+2| &< \epsilon \\
2|x+1| &< \epsilon \\
2|x-(-1)| &< \epsilon \\
|x-(-1)| &< \frac{\epsilon}{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

Given $\epsilon > 0$, Choose $\delta = \frac{\epsilon}{2}$, thus,

$$
\begin{aligned}
|x+1| &< \delta \\
|x+1| &< \frac{\epsilon}{2} \\
2|x+1| &< \epsilon \\
|2x+2| &< \epsilon \\
|2x+1+1| &< \epsilon \\
|2x+1-(-1)| &< \epsilon \\
\end{aligned}
$$

\item[2)] Determine all the numbers $c$ which satisfy the conclusions of
the Mean Value Theorem for the following function and graph
using R with the point/s identified. $f(x)=x^3-4x^2-2x-5$ on $[-10,10]$.

Solution:

$$
\begin{aligned}
f'(c) &= \frac{f(b)-f(a)}{b-a} \\
3c^2 - 8c - 2 &= \frac{[(10)^3-4(10)-2(10)-5]-[(-10)^3-4(-10)-2(-10)-5]}{10-(-10)} \\
3c^2 - 8c - 2 &= \frac{575 - (-1385)}{20} \\
3c^2 - 8c - 2 &= 98 \\
3c^2 - 8c - 100 &= 0 \\
c &= \frac{-(-8) \pm \sqrt{(-8)^2 - 4(3)(-100)}}{6} \\
c &= \frac{8 \pm \sqrt{1264}}{6} \\
c &= \frac{8 \pm 4\sqrt{79}}{6} \\ 
c &\approx -4.59 \\
c &\approx 7.25
\end{aligned}
$$


\item[3)] Find the point $c$ that satisfies the mean value theorem for
integrals on the interval $[-1,1]$. The function is $f(x)=2e^x$

Solution:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\int_{-1}^{1} 2e^x dx &= (2e^c)(1-(-1)) \\
2e^x \Big|_{-1}^{1} &= (2e^c)2 \\
(2e-2e^{-1}) &= 4e^c\\ 
\frac{2(e-e^{-1})}{4} &= e^c \\ 
\frac{(e-e^{-1})}{2} &= e^c \\ 
\ln{\left( \frac{(e-e^{-1})}{2} \right)} &= c \\
0.16143936157 &\approx  c
\end{aligned}
$$

\end{itemize}
